perturbation.original_text: California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043 provide rights to you concerning termination or non-renewal of a franchise. If the Master Franchise Agreement contains provisions that are inconsistent with the law, the law will control.
perturbation.changed_text: California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043 provide rights to you concerning termination or non-renewal of a franchise. Even if the Master Franchise Agreement contains provisions that are inconsistent with the law, the Master Franchise Agreement will control.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts California law, which states that the law controls in cases of inconsistency between franchise agreements and the Business and Professions Code concerning termination or non-renewal. The modified text attempts to supersede state law, making it legally unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043

perturbation.original_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires non-binding mediation. The mediation will occur in New York with the costs being borne by equally by the parties. Prospective franchisees are encouraged to consult private legal counsel to determine the applicability of California and federal laws (such as Business and Professions Code Section 20040.5 and Code of Civil Procedure Section 1281) to any provisions of a franchise agreement restricting venue to a forum outside the State of California.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires non-binding mediation. The mediation will occur in New York with all costs borne solely by the franchisee. Prospective franchisees are not required to consult legal counsel regarding the applicability of California or federal laws.
perturbation.explanation: This modification is inconsistent with California law and general principles of fairness in franchise agreements. Requiring the franchisee to bear all mediation costs in a forum outside of California can be considered an unconscionable burden. Further, discouraging consultation with legal counsel directly undermines the franchisee's ability to understand their rights and obligations, which is against public policy and potentially violates disclosure requirements under California franchise law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 20040.5 and Code of Civil Procedure Section 1281 (related to venue restrictions) and potentially California Corporations Code 31000 et seq. (Franchise Investment Law) regarding disclosure obligations.

perturbation.original_text: You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. California Corporation Code 31512 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516). Business and Professions Code 20010 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043).
perturbation.changed_text: You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. By signing this agreement, you explicitly waive all rights under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516) and the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043).
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts California Corporation Code 31512 and Business and Professions Code 20010, which explicitly void waivers of rights under the Franchise Investment Law and the Franchise Relations Act, respectively. The modified text attempts to enforce a waiver that is legally invalid under California law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Corporation Code 31512 and Business and Professions Code 20010
